summary: This is a legal petition filed by a victim (Jane Doe) through her attorney Brad Edwards, seeking enforcement of her rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) in relation to the federal criminal investigation and plea negotiations involving Jeffrey Epstein. The petition alleges the victim was denied her rights to confer with prosecutors and receive notice regarding Epstein's potential plea deal.

events.title: Enactment of Crime Victims' Rights Act
events.description: Congress passed and the President signed into law the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA), giving crime victims enforceable rights to participate in federal criminal proceedings.

keyFacts: The petition reveals active federal plea negotiations between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office in July 2008, which the victim feared would proceed without her input.
It states Jeffrey Epstein had already pleaded guilty to state charges (solicitation of minors for prostitution) on June 30, 2008.
The document alleges the victim (Jane Doe) was lured to Epstein's mansion under false pretenses for a massage, where he then demanded sexual acts in exchange for payment.
It cites the Fifth Circuit case 'In re Dean' (2008) which held the government violated the CVRA by negotiating a plea agreement without conferring with victims.
The petition argues CVRA rights apply during the investigation phase, before any charges are formally filed.
